title: Django for Everybody (DJ4E)
description: Hello and welcome to my site where you can work through these modules and learn develop Python / Django database-backed web applications.

modules.title: HyperText Markup Language (HTML)
modules.description: We briefly cover the basics of the HyperText Markup Language (HTML) that is the markup for web pages.

modules.title: Introduction to Dynamic Web Content
modules.description: We look at the basic structure of a web application and how a web browser interacts with a web server.   We explore the Request-Response Cycle that is the basis of the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP).

videos.title: Web Applications and the Request/Response Cycle

references.title: What Happens When You Click a Link? - Computerphile

modules.title: Installing Django on PythonAnywhere
modules.description: This walks through the installation steps for Django on PythonAnywhere.  If you cannot use PythonAnywhere, you can also install Django locally and submit assignments your local computer for grading.  Installing Django locally will be described in an upcoming lesson.

references.title: Setting up a Django Environment (Mozilla Developer Network)
Using ngrok to submit a local application to the Autograder
Setting up the django.org tutorial on PythonAnywhere

modules.title: Putting your Django Projects into GitHub
modules.description: This optional exercise uploads your Django projects on PythonAnywhere to a private repository on GitHub if you have access to private repositories.  Please do not put your assignments in a public GitHub repository. Github provides free private repositories for small numbers of collaborators.

videos.title: Using GitHub with Django and PythonAnywhere

references.title: Unlimited Free Private Repositories on GitHub
Caching your GitHub password in Linux

modules.title: Installing Django skeleton site
modules.description: Skeleton Web Site Tutorial from Mozilla Developers Network.

videos.title: MDN Skeleton Web Site on PythonAnywhere

modules.title: Basic SQL
modules.description: This is a quick look at the basic operations (CRUD) in Structured Query Language (SQL).

references.title: Liz Fong: Creating the SQL Database Standards

modules.title: Django Models
modules.description: This exercise adds models for the LocalLibrary web site.

references.title: Models Tutorial from Mozilla Developers Network

modules.title: Django admin site
modules.description: This exercise works through the Django admin interface for the LocalLibrary web site.

references.title: Admin Tutorial from Mozilla Developers Network

modules.title: Installing Django locally
modules.description: This is an optional exercise to install Django locally to both speed your development cycles and to play with the sample code.  The next module inludes quite a bit of new code so you will be able to develpp more quickly with Django installed locally.  You can submit your assignments from your local computer using a technology called 'ngrok'.

references.title: Setting up a Django Environment (Mozilla Developer Network)
Using ngrok to submit a local application to the Autograder

modules.title: Django home page
modules.description: This exercise builds our first top level view (the home page) for the LocalLibrary web site.

references.title: Home Page Tutorial from Mozilla Developers Network

modules.title: Django detail
modules.description: This exercise builds detail views for the LocalLibrary web site.

references.title: Detail Pages Tutorial from Mozilla Developers Network
Django Documentation: Generic list display views
Django Documentation: Generic detail display views

modules.title: Django sessions
modules.description: This exercise uses sessions on the LocalLibrary web site.  This exercises is quite simple so there is no video walkthrough.

modules.title: Django Users and Authentication
modules.description: This exercise explores the interaction between authentication and our application.

modules.title: Django Forms and CRUD
modules.description: This exercise builds some basic forms and a full set of Create, Read, and Update (CRUD) forms.

references.title: Authentication Tutorial from Mozilla Developers Network
Forms Tutorial from Mozilla Developers Network

modules.title: Autos CRUD Application
modules.description: In this assignment we build a smaller CRUD application from scratch to support an autos database that we will use as a base to build on going forward.   This will serve as a way to review some of the concepts in the tutorial that we might have covered a little too quickly.

modules.title: Review: Cascading Style Sheets (CSS)
modules.description: We briefly cover the basics of cascading Style Sheets (CSS) that allow us to style the markup for web pages.

references.title: Web Developer Plugin by Chris Pedrick
CSS Cheat Sheet by Leslie Frank

json.title: Cascading Style Sheets
json.description: In this assignment you will develop a Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) to control, the look, feel, and layout of some provide HTML content.
json.grading: This is a relatively simple assignment.  Don't take off points for little mistakes.  If they seem to have done the assignment give them full credit.   Feel free to make suggestions if there are small mistakes.  Please keep your comments positive and useful.  If you do not take grading seriously, the instructors may delete your response and you will lose points.

parts.title: Image (JPG or PNG) of your index.htm with the styling applied
The source code of your blocks.css file
Image (JPG or PNG) of your blocks.css passing the W3 CSS validator
Image (JPG or PNG) of your browser viewing www.brainyquote.com with all styles turned off
Image (JPG or PNG) of your browser at www.brainyquote.com inspecting the navigation element to find its background color

modules.title: Project Overview
modules.description: Introduce your project to the rest of the class.

json.title: Milestone 1: Describe Your Project
json.description: Please describe your proposed Django database-backed web site project in 1-2 paragraphs.   Talk about the scope of the project, similar web sites, the kind of data the project will store and show and the interactive elements that get data from logged-in end users.
json.grading: This assignment is worth 10 points. 6 points come from your peers and 4 points come from you grading other student's submissions. Don't take off points for little mistakes.  If they seem to have done the assignment give them full credit.   Feel free to make suggestions if there are small mistakes.  Please keep your comments positive and useful.  If you do not take grading seriously, the instructors may delete your response and you will lose points.

parts.title: URL of your GitHub Repo - If it is private just put in your github account url and mention that your repo is private below
Please describe your project in a few paragraphs.

modules.title: Project Milestone 2
modules.description: Introduce your project to the rest of the class.

json.title: Milestone 2: Revise your Project Description
json.description: For this milestone, you will revise your 1-2 paragraph summary of your project idea and add a short paragraph describing what the changes are and why you are making the changes.  If you are not making any changes briefly describe anything you have learned or improved on your description.
json.grading: This assignment is worth 10 points. 6 points come from your peers and 4 points come from you grading other student's submissions. Don't take off points for little mistakes.  If they seem to have done the assignment give them full credit.   Feel free to make suggestions if there are small mistakes.  Please keep your comments positive and useful.  If you do not take grading seriously, the instructors may delete your response and you will lose points.

parts.title: URL of your GitHub Repo - If it is private just put in your github account url and mention that your repo is private below
Please describe your project (again) in a few paragraphs.

modules.title: Project Milestone 3
modules.description: Design a first verson of the user interface (UI) for your project.

json.title: Milestone 3: User Interface Brainstorm
json.description: For this milestone, you will begin to develop the user interface for your project. Like in previous milestones, you will get a chance to revise your UI design and can still change it quite dramatically with no negative consequences.
json.grading: This assignment is worth 10 points. 6 points come from your peers and 4 points come from you grading other student's submissions. Don't take off points for little mistakes.  If they seem to have done the assignment give them full credit.   Feel free to make suggestions if there are small mistakes.  Please keep your comments positive and useful.  If you do not take grading seriously, the instructors may delete your response and you will lose points.

parts.title: URL of your GitHub Repo - If it is private just put in your github account url and mention that your repo is private below
Please describe your UI Design images.  If you have less than 4 images, mention that here and upload an image of a cat, race car with cat ears, or somthing else fun and appropriate.
